verses.text: After two days, the Passover and the Feast of Unleavened Bread were coming. The chief priests and the scribes were seeking a way to arrest Jesus by stealth and kill him.
verses.comment: Mark sets the scene, showing the plot against Jesus coincides with Passover, foreshadowing Jesus as the true Passover lamb (see Ex. 12:21–27).

verses.text: But they said, 'Not during the feast, lest there be an uproar among the people.'
verses.comment: Jesus remains popular with the people, so his adversaries fear a riot. Divine timing prevails over human plotting.

verses.text: And while he was at Bethany in the house of Simon the leper, as he was reclining at table, a woman came with an alabaster jar of very costly pure nard, and she broke the jar and poured it on his head.
verses.comment: The anointing is a gesture of great honor typically reserved for kings or priests (1 Sam. 10:1). Here, Jesus is symbolically anointed, foreshadowing his burial.

verses.text: Some were indignant to themselves, saying, 'Why was this ointment wasted?'
verses.comment: An inward complaint; human concerns about 'waste' miss the greater significance of loving devotion to Jesus.

verses.text: 'This ointment could have been sold for more than three hundred denarii and given to the poor.' And they rebuked her harshly.
verses.comment: Three hundred denarii was about a year's wage. The tension between practical charity and lavish worship recurs throughout Scripture.

verses.text: But Jesus said, 'Leave her alone. Why do you trouble her? She has done a beautiful thing to me.'
verses.comment: Jesus prioritizes honor and loving devotion over other concerns. True worship often transcends practicality.

verses.text: 'For you always have the poor with you, and whenever you want, you can do good for them. But you will not always have me.'
verses.comment: Jesus quotes Deuteronomy, making a distinction. His presence is unique; honoring Him is paramount during His ministry.

verses.text: 'She has done what she could; she has anointed my body beforehand for burial.'
verses.comment: The anointing prefigures the preparations for Jesus’ burial, highlighting His coming death and resurrection.

verses.text: 'Truly I tell you, wherever the gospel is preached in the whole world, what she has done will be told in memory of her.'
verses.comment: Jesus promises enduring remembrance; the value of her act is elevated to a model for all Christians.

verses.text: Then Judas Iscariot, one of the twelve, went to the chief priests to betray him to them.
verses.comment: Judas’ betrayal for money contrasts the woman’s costly devotion. Theologically, betrayal by an insider fulfills prophecy (Ps. 41:9).

verses.text: When they heard it, they were glad and promised to give him money. So he began looking for an opportunity to betray Jesus.
verses.comment: Judas’ actions are part of God’s permitted plan, not mere accident, fitting Old Testament themes of betrayal.

verses.text: On the first day of Unleavened Bread, when they sacrificed the Passover lamb, his disciples said to him, 'Where do you want us to go and prepare for you to eat the Passover?'
verses.comment: Preparation for Passover underscores Jesus’ role as the true Paschal lamb (see 1 Cor. 5:7).

verses.text: He sent two of his disciples and said to them, 'Go into the city, and a man carrying a jar of water will meet you. Follow him.'
verses.comment: Jesus’ foreknowledge and arrangement show his divine authority and the fulfillment of specific prophecy.

verses.text: 'Wherever he enters, say to the owner of the house, “The Teacher says, ‘Where is my guest room, where I may eat the Passover with my disciples?’”'
verses.comment: Jesus acts as the authoritative Teacher (Rabbi), implying supernatural coordination.

verses.text: 'He will show you a large upper room furnished and ready. Make preparations for us there.'
verses.comment: The upper room becomes the setting for a pivotal event in Christian tradition: the Last Supper.

verses.text: So the disciples set out and went into the city and found things just as he had told them, and they prepared the Passover.
verses.comment: Jesus’ prophecy is exactly fulfilled; his authority over events is evident.

verses.text: When it was evening, he arrived with the twelve.
verses.comment: The evening time matches Passover tradition (Ex. 12:8).

verses.text: As they were reclining at table and eating, Jesus said, 'Truly I tell you, one of you will betray me—one who is eating with me.'
verses.comment: Betrayal by one sharing bread fulfills Psalmic prophecy (Ps. 41:9). Shared meals denote intimacy, so betrayal is all the more tragic.

verses.text: They began to be sorrowful and say to him one after another, 'Is it I?'
verses.comment: Shows human humility and self-examination in light of potential failure.

verses.text: He said to them, 'It is one of the twelve, one who is dipping bread into the bowl with me.'
verses.comment: Jesus explicitly identifies the betrayer as an insider, again fulfilling Old Testament prophecy.

verses.text: 'For the Son of Man goes as it is written about him, but woe to that man by whom the Son of Man is betrayed! It would have been better for him if he had not been born.'
verses.comment: Necessity of prophecy fulfillment with personal accountability. Divine sovereignty and human responsibility are both affirmed.

verses.text: And as they were eating, he took bread, and after blessing it, broke it and gave it to them and said, 'Take; this is my body.'
verses.comment: Christ institutes the breaking of bread as his body—a literal and mystical act. The real presence of Christ in the bread has been understood by Christians through the ages. Spiritual Communion and unity are signified (John 6:47–51).

verses.text: And he took a cup, and when he had given thanks, he gave it to them, and they all drank from it.
verses.comment: Sharing the cup symbolizes covenant and fellowship. Note the unity signified; all drank from the same cup.

verses.text: And he said to them, 'This is my blood of the covenant, which is poured out for many.'
verses.comment: Blood establishes covenant, reminiscent of Exodus. Christ's blood is poured out, fulfilling Isaiah's prophecy of the suffering servant.

verses.text: 'Truly I tell you, I will not drink again of the fruit of the vine until that day when I drink it new in the kingdom of God.'
verses.comment: Points to future fulfillment in God's kingdom—a promise of restoration and heavenly fellowship.

verses.text: When they had sung a hymn, they went out to the Mount of Olives.
verses.comment: The hymn likely refers to the Passover Hallel psalms (Ps. 115–118), connecting the event to Jewish tradition.

verses.text: And Jesus said to them, 'All of you will fall away, for it is written, “I will strike the shepherd, and the sheep will be scattered.”'
verses.comment: Jesus fulfills Zechariah’s prophecy, affirming the scattering of His followers but implicitly promising restoration.

verses.text: 'But after I am raised up, I will go ahead of you to Galilee.'
verses.comment: First explicit promise of the Resurrection and reunion. Galilee will be a place of restoration.

verses.text: Peter said to him, 'Even if all fall away, I will not.'
verses.comment: Peter’s boldness foreshadows his coming failure and subsequent restoration as leader.

verses.text: And Jesus said to him, 'Truly I tell you, this very night, before the rooster crows twice, you will deny me three times.'
verses.comment: Threefold denial is prophetic. Such specificity hints at Jesus’ divine foreknowledge.

verses.text: But Peter insisted emphatically, 'Even if I have to die with you, I will never deny you.' And all the others said the same.
verses.comment: Emphasizes human frailty and the need for God's grace, seen in Peter’s eventual repentance and restoration.

verses.text: They came to a place called Gethsemane, and he said to his disciples, 'Sit here while I pray.'
verses.comment: Gethsemane means 'oil press', symbolizing Jesus being 'pressed' for humanity’s sake.

verses.text: And he took Peter, James, and John along with him, and he began to be greatly distressed and troubled.
verses.comment: Significant moments often involve Peter, James, and John, whom Jesus prepares for leadership.

verses.text: He said to them, 'My soul is overwhelmed with sorrow, even to the point of death. Stay here and keep watch.'
verses.comment: Jesus' true humanity is shown—He experiences deep sorrow. The instruction to 'watch' is echoed for all believers (Mark 13:33–37).

verses.text: Going a little farther, he fell to the ground and prayed that, if it were possible, the hour might pass from him.
verses.comment: Here is true humanity—submission and anguish, yet a willingness to obey the Father’s will.

verses.text: He said, 'Abba, Father, all things are possible for you. Take this cup away from me. Yet not what I will, but what you will.'
verses.comment: Jesus uses the intimate address ‘Abba’. Obedience unto death is an essential theme in Christian discipleship.

verses.text: He returned and found them sleeping, and said to Peter, 'Simon, are you sleeping? Could you not keep watch for one hour?'
verses.comment: Peter’s inability to stay awake again anticipates his later failure. The call to spiritual vigilance is repeated.

verses.text: 'Watch and pray that you may not enter into temptation. The spirit indeed is willing, but the flesh is weak.'
verses.comment: A reminder of the need for grace through vigilant prayer. Human frailty calls for spiritual discipline and sacramental help.

verses.text: Again he went away and prayed, repeating the same words.
verses.comment: Persistence in prayer is modeled for believers.

verses.text: He returned and found them sleeping again, for their eyes were heavy, and they did not know what to say to him.
verses.comment: Shows the disciples' limitations and lack of understanding; points to the need for supernatural strengthening.

verses.text: And he came the third time and said to them, 'Are you still sleeping and resting? Enough! The hour has come. The Son of Man is betrayed into the hands of sinners.'
verses.comment: The reference to 'third time' echoes Peter's future denial and the completeness of a sequence in Hebrew thought.

verses.text: 'Rise, let us go. See, my betrayer is at hand.'
verses.comment: Jesus’ willingness to face betrayal models courageous obedience and the acceptance of God’s will.

verses.text: Immediately, while he was still speaking, Judas, one of the twelve, arrived, and with him a crowd armed with swords and clubs, sent by the chief priests, the scribes, and the elders.
verses.comment: The coming of armed men against Jesus fulfills the wisdom literature’s image of the righteous being persecuted (Ps. 22:16).

verses.text: Now the betrayer had given them a signal: 'The one I kiss is the man; arrest him and lead him away under guard.'
verses.comment: A kiss, sign of affection, betrays Jesus; echoes betrayal themes (Ps. 41:9).

verses.text: When Judas came, he went straight to Jesus and said, 'Rabbi!' and kissed him.
verses.comment: Judas calls Jesus ‘Rabbi’ but honors Him only externally.

verses.text: Then they laid hands on Jesus and arrested him.
verses.comment: Jesus is physically seized, yet submits freely; a critical step in His passion.

verses.text: But one of those standing nearby drew his sword and struck the servant of the high priest, cutting off his ear.
verses.comment: The swordsman is identified as Peter elsewhere. The impulsive act shows human zeal, but Jesus will heal and restore.

verses.text: Jesus said to them, 'Have you come out with swords and clubs to arrest me as if I were a robber?'
verses.comment: Jesus exposes the injustice of their actions and His innocence.

verses.text: 'Every day I was with you in the temple teaching, and you did not arrest me. But let the Scriptures be fulfilled.'
verses.comment: Jesus submits to prophecy, underscoring His obedience to Scripture as the suffering servant.

verses.text: Then all his disciples deserted him and fled.
verses.comment: Fulfills Zechariah's prophecy; even closest followers fall away, highlighting need for restoration and forgiveness.

verses.text: A young man followed him, wearing only a linen cloth. When they seized him,
verses.comment: Traditionally thought to be Mark. Linen cloth can symbolize baptismal garment—following Jesus in vulnerability.

verses.text: he left the cloth and fled away naked.
verses.comment: The nakedness is a symbol of humanity’s vulnerability post-betrayal, echoing Eden’s shame after the fall (Gen. 3:7).

verses.text: They took Jesus to the high priest, and all the chief priests, elders, and scribes gathered together.
verses.comment: Jesus stands before the religious authorities, setting the scene for his trial and the fulfillment of suffering prophecies.

verses.text: And Peter followed him at a distance, right into the courtyard of the high priest. He sat with the guards and warmed himself at the fire.
verses.comment: Peter’s distancing is literal and spiritual; soon his denial will be evident.

verses.text: Now the chief priests and the whole council were seeking testimony against Jesus to put him to death, but they found none.
verses.comment: Jesus, the sinless one, fulfills the prophecy of the suffering and innocent servant (Isa. 53:9).

verses.text: Many gave false testimony against him, but their testimonies did not agree.
verses.comment: False witness further fulfills the Psalms about the righteous suffering unjustly.

verses.text: Some stood up and gave false witness against him, saying,
verses.comment: Jesus is falsely accused, linking to Old Testament scenes where the righteous are maligned.

verses.text: 'We heard him say, “I will destroy this temple made with hands, and in three days I will build another, not made with hands.”'
verses.comment: Refers to Jesus’ claim to rebuild the temple, which symbolically refers to his resurrection (temple of his body).

verses.text: But even then their testimony did not agree.
verses.comment: Their attempt to condemn Jesus fails due to lack of truthful, consistent testimony—pointing to his innocence.

verses.text: Then the high priest stood up in the midst and asked Jesus, 'Do you make no answer? What is it these witnesses are saying against you?'
verses.comment: The silence of Jesus fulfills prophecy: the silent lamb before its shearers (Isa. 53:7).

verses.text: But he remained silent and made no answer. Again the high priest asked him, 'Are you the Christ, the Son of the Blessed?'
verses.comment: ‘Son of the Blessed’ is a reverent Jewish phrase for Son of God. Jesus’ silence fulfills prophecy and prepares for His explicit declaration.

verses.text: Jesus said, 'I am, and you will see the Son of Man seated at the right hand of Power, and coming with the clouds of heaven.'
verses.comment: Here Jesus explicitly claims divinity, invoking ‘I AM’ (echoes Ex. 3:14) and Danielic messianic expectation. To sit at God’s right hand is a claim to unique authority.

verses.text: Then the high priest tore his robes and said, 'What further need do we have for witnesses?'
verses.comment: Tearing robes is a sign of great grief or outrage. Here, it is a response to alleged blasphemy.

verses.text: 'You have heard the blasphemy. What is your decision?' And they all condemned him as deserving death.
verses.comment: Condemnation is based on Jesus' claim to divinity and messianic status. This fulfills the prophecy of the suffering servant rejected (Isa. 53:3).

verses.text: Then some began to spit on him, cover his face, and strike him, saying to him, 'Prophesy!' And the guards received him with blows.
verses.comment: The mocking and abuse fulfill Psalm 22 and Isaiah’s portrait of the suffering servant.

verses.text: While Peter was below in the courtyard, one of the servant girls of the high priest came by.
verses.comment: Peter’s location sets up his threefold denial, an episode that highlights human weakness and later restoration.

verses.text: When she saw Peter warming himself, she looked at him and said, 'You also were with the Nazarene, Jesus.'
verses.comment: Identification with Jesus can lead to persecution, yet Peter here denies.

verses.text: But he denied it, saying, ‘I neither know nor understand what you are talking about.’ And he went out into the gateway, and the rooster crowed.
verses.comment: The first denial is marked by evasive words. The rooster’s crow signals the progression of prophecy.

verses.text: When the servant girl saw him again, she began to say to those standing nearby, 'This is one of them.'
verses.comment: Peter is again accused of association with Jesus. The growing pressure challenges his resolve.

verses.text: But again he denied it. After a little while, those standing by said to Peter, 'Surely you are one of them, for you are a Galilean.'
verses.comment: Galilean accent betrayed Peter. Association with Jesus requires courage—Peter’s later repentance is significant.

verses.text: He began to curse and swear, 'I do not know this man you are talking about.'
verses.comment: Peter’s denial reaches its climax. Human weakness and the need for divine forgiveness are evident.

verses.text: Immediately the rooster crowed a second time. And Peter remembered how Jesus had said to him, 'Before the rooster crows twice, you will deny me three times.' And he broke down and wept.
verses.comment: Peter’s repentance prepares him for future leadership. Restoration after failure is possible through God’s mercy. The sequence highlights the importance of confession and forgiveness in Christian life.
